metadata.description: Exergy quality factors for different end-use sectors based on thermodynamic value
metadata.methodology: IEA Energy Efficiency Indicators (EEI) exergy analysis methodology
sources: IEA Energy Efficiency Indicators (EEI) - Sectoral exergy framework
IEA World Energy Outlook 2024 - Exergy efficiency data
Brockway et al. 2019 - Exergy chains analysis of global energy flows
Cullen & Allwood 2010 - Theoretical minimum energy demand
metadata.key_insight: Exergy accounts for thermodynamic quality: mechanical work and electricity are 100% quality, low-temperature heat is 7% quality (v2.8 update to align with Brockway 2019 strict Carnot minimum)

mechanical_work.description: Transport (vehicles, aviation, shipping, rail) - mechanical motion

electricity.description: High-quality energy that can perform any task

low_temp_space_heating.description: Space heating, water heating, cooking - temperatures <100°C. Strict Carnot minimum per Brockway et al. 2019: η = 1 - T_ambient/T_service ≈ 1 - 273K/293K = 0.068 ≈ 0.07

notes.exergy_definition: Exergy is the maximum useful work obtainable from a given energy source. It accounts for both quantity and quality of energy.
notes.temperature_dependence: Exergy factor = 1 - (T_ambient / T_process) for heat applications. Higher temperature processes have higher exergy. Low-temp heating (20°C service, 0°C ambient) has strict Carnot minimum of 0.068 ≈ 0.07 per Brockway et al. 2019.
notes.electricity_exergy: Electricity has exergy factor of 1.0 because it can be fully converted to any other energy form (limited only by device efficiency).
notes.heat_exergy: Low-temperature heat has low exergy because thermodynamic limits prevent efficient conversion to work or electricity (Carnot efficiency). Brockway et al. 2019 uses stricter analysis (~0.10-0.15 for space heating).
notes.application: Energy Services (EJ) = Useful Energy (EJ) × Exergy Quality Factor
notes.storage_losses: Storage losses removed from exergy factors to avoid double-counting (already included in efficiency factors). Transmission & distribution losses (5%) now applied equally to both fossil and clean electricity generation.
notes.brockway_extrapolation: Brockway et al. 2019 provides EROI ratios and exergy framework, not direct global EJ totals. Baseline ~100 EJ services (2015) extrapolated to ~120-130 EJ (2024) accounting for energy demand growth and efficiency improvements.
